content.webTitle: Ben Davies believes hard yards have given Tottenham’s title run legs

fields.headline: Ben Davies believes hard yards have given Tottenham’s title run legs
fields.bodyText: It is often said that the season is a marathon, not a sprint, and if that is the case Tottenham Hotspur are in a good position to go on and win their first league title since 1961. Mauricio Pochettino’s team were in second place as they trained for Sunday’s game against fourth-placed Manchester City and a big reason for their lofty position is their supreme fitness. The Argentinian has been working on ensuring his players are in prime shape since he walked through the door in 2014 and the players now feel they are stronger and fitter than any other team. The full-back Ben Davies joined Spurs from Swansea City the same summer as Pochettino and believes their fitness gives them an edge over their rivals, especially in the latter stages of games. “When you first start putting all the work in, it’s tough, you have to be determined enough to be able to put up with it every day to get yourself fit and maybe at times it gets hard but now maybe we see the rewards out on the field,” he says. “We’re covering more distance than teams, we’re able to press teams and not give them a moment on the ball. That’s not just for 20-30 minutes, that’s throughout the whole game. The amount of goals and way we play towards the end of games really does show with the fitness, and as players you’re able to keep going for longer.” Davies says that Pochettino is keen for the players to work with, rather than without, the ball during the season but that it is still the toughest regime he has come across, and something he was not quite prepared for when he left the Liberty Stadium. “The intensity [was] something totally new to me,” he says. “I go back with Wales and tell them the amount of training we’re doing and some of the players can’t believe it. But we’re not complaining when we’re second in the league and we’re playing better than a lot of teams in this league. It makes us feel proud of it.” The Wales international also believes Tottenham’s good form means the players keep pushing each other to even better performances. In short, there is no time to be tired. “We’ve got a big squad here and, if you are tired, you’ve got fresh players ready to come in,” he says. “So, in other words, don’t be tired.” It is easy to say, perhaps, when things are going well but Spurs potentially have another 22 games this season, if they reach the Europa League final, after the 35 already contested. Davies admits Pochettino is a hard man to please, but says that is part of what has made them play so well. “Every manager has got to have that strictness about them, but you know, he’s got every player’s respect here and everyone’s bought into exactly what he wants. The easiest way for a player to buy into it is when results start coming, which they have for us, and if we keep going this way then we’ll do well.” Spurs are sure to keep going against Manchester City on Sunday and for the remaining 12 league games because it is what Pochettino has set them up to do.
